docs.lead_paragraph: Even as members of the Obama administration and Congress met Thursday to try to find common ground on health care, a new report warned that without comprehensive legislation, more than 275,000 adults nationwide would die over the next decade because of a lack of health insurance. Nearly 14,000 of the deaths would occur in New York State, said the report, done by the liberal advocacy group Families USA.
docs.abstract: Families USA report warns that without comprehensive health care legislation, more than 275,000 adults nationwide would die over next decade because of lack of health insurance; nearly 14,000 of deaths would occur in New York State (S)
docs.snippet: Even as members of the Obama administration and Congress met Thursday to try to find common ground on health care, a new report warned that without comprehensive legislation, more than 275,000 adults nationwide would die over the next decade because...

docs.lead_paragraph: It's a long way from Vancouver, but there there was an Olympian clash at the White House guest cabana Thursday, and despite the cloudy outlook, conditions didn't result in a debilitating outbreak of bipartisanship. So, who were the big winners and losers of Health Care Brouhaha of 2010? Let's first focus on the man in the middle of it all:

headline.main: Health Care's Clash of the Titans

docs.abstract: So who won the bipartisan summit? (Hint: it wasn't bipartisanship.)
docs.snippet: So who won the bipartisan summit? (Hint: it wasn't bipartisanship.)

docs.lead_paragraph: Better health doesn't seem to explain why so many young people forgo health insurance. Rather, income does, according to new survey data released by Gallup.

headline.main: Driving the Young From the Insurance Pool

docs.abstract: Better health doesn't seem to explain why so many young adults forgo health insurance. Rather, income does, according to new survey data released by Gallup.
docs.snippet: Better health doesn't seem to explain why so many young adults forgo health insurance. Rather, income does, according to new survey data released by Gallup.

docs.lead_paragraph: This week, I sat down with Esther Dyson, who began her career as a journalist, moved to Wall Street, wrote a popular technology newsletter and is now investing in health technology and training to be a space tourist.

headline.main: One on One: Esther Dyson, Health Tech Investor and Space Tourist

docs.abstract: Esther Dyson, investor and technologist, discusses technology that tracks your health and why she thinks you will want to use it.
docs.snippet: Esther Dyson, investor and technologist, discusses technology that tracks your health and why she thinks you will want to use it.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than $1 in every $10 that American banks have outstanding in loans is lent to a troubled borrower, a ratio far higher than previously seen in the quarter-century that such numbers have been compiled, The New York Times's Floyd Norris writes in his Off the Charts column.

headline.main: Think Banks Are Out of the Woods? Maybe Not

docs.abstract: The large number of problem loans held by banks provides a stark reminder that the banking system remains in perilous health, Floyd Norris writes in his Off the Charts column.
docs.snippet: The large number of problem loans held by banks provides a stark reminder that the banking system remains in perilous health, Floyd Norris writes in his Off the Charts column.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jon Chait responds to my qualified praise for the idea of a scaled-back health care bill:
docs.abstract: Why a bill that targets children and the near-poor makes moral sense.
docs.snippet: Why a bill that targets children and the near-poor makes moral sense.

docs.lead_paragraph: 6:15 p.m. | Updated More from Economix: A new Gallup poll sheds light on why young people don't buy health insurance. And at Media Decoder, the White House says it served up millions of live streams for the summit yesterday.

headline.main: New Developments in the Health Care Debate

docs.abstract: Prominent economists call for Congress to overhaul health care, and other news related to the health care debate from Times bloggers.
docs.snippet: Prominent economists call for Congress to overhaul health care, and other news related to the health care debate from Times bloggers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Obviously, not all economists are in favor of the current proposals in Congress. But a pretty impressive group of health economists and other policy experts has released a letter making the following argument:

headline.main: Health Economists Urge Passage of Reform

docs.abstract: A group of economists and other health experts argue that the current bills are much better than the alternatives.
docs.snippet: A group of economists and other health experts argue that the current bills are much better than the alternatives.

docs.lead_paragraph: As members of the Obama administration and Congress met on Thursday to try to find common ground on health care, a new report warned that without comprehensive legislation, more than 275,000 adults nationwide will die over the next decade because of a lack of health insurance. Nearly 14,000 of those deaths would occur in New York State.

headline.main: Deaths Rising for Lack of Insurance, Study Finds

docs.abstract: In the absence of comprehensive health care legislation, a lack of insurance will contribute to 275,000 deaths over the next decade, an advocacy group warned on Thursday.
docs.snippet: In the absence of comprehensive health care legislation, a lack of insurance will contribute to 275,000 deaths over the next decade, an advocacy group warned on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: In anticipation of tax season, we have turned to a series of experts who focus on specialized areas of tax finance. In our first series, we focused on freelancers. In our second installment, we're looking at same-sex couples and the unique issues they face.

headline.main: Answers About Same-Sex Couples and Taxes: Part 4

docs.abstract: In our fourth installment of Ask the Expert, Tina Salandra, a certified public accountant, continues to answer questions from same-sex couples about taxes.
docs.snippet: In our fourth installment of Ask the Expert, Tina Salandra, a certified public accountant, continues to answer questions from same-sex couples about taxes.
